intro: Nierembergia gracilis var. guaranitica, commonly known as the Guarani bellflower, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Brazil. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and riverbanks. It has slender, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers bloom in clusters, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation efforts.
